utterances: If YouTube is the world's number one video sharing site, then what is YouTube's number one most popular video?
(Soundbite of song ""Twist"" by Chuck Berry)
It's this six minute performance viewed more than 37 million times, aptly titled ""The Evolution of Dance."" A young man twists, discos and breaks through, well, the history of dance.
(Soundbite of music)
The closest contender for the top spot, two college guys lip-synching along with the theme song for the children's show Pokemon.
That's only been seen 18 million times in the year that it's been on YouTube.
Well, if 2006 was the year of YouTube, what will be the online star of 2007?
Hiawatha Bray writes about technology for the Boston Globe.
And Hiawatha, what would you project the big Internet phenomenon of 2007 might be?
I have no idea.
There's no telling.
There's no telling what is going to really capture people's imagination.
All I can go by are the things that I've seen recently that have captured mine.
The two that really immediately leap out are one that's a free online service that's sort of reminiscent of YouTube.
The other one's a commercial service that solves a desperate problem that just hasn't been addressed properly in the computing world.
Let's talk about the free service first.
What's that?
Absolutely.
The free service is called Wikimapia.
It's what's known as a mash-up.
That's one of those phenomena where you take an existing Internet service and then you combine it with other software to make something really new.
In this case what they've done is they've gone to Google Earth, the famous service that allows you to see satellite images of anywhere on the planet.
They've combined that with their own Wiki software to create a service in which anybody in the world can now create a geographical guide to anyplace in the world.

If you have a particular spot on earth that means something to you, that's very important to you, that you are an expert on, you go to Wikimapia and you write all the information on it yourself and that becomes now, in effect, the sort of visual encyclopedia of that spot on earth.
It's a brilliant idea.
Okay, so that's Wikimapia.
That's the free service you were talking about.
It's a free service.
And you mentioned something that would cost a little money.
What's that?
The one that costs money solves the ultimate computer problem - data backup.
How do you keep from losing all your information in an age where almost all of us keep all our information on our hard drives?
There's a company in Boston that has finally found a good solution to it called Carbonite.
You pay them $50 a year.
You plug into a broadband Internet connection.
That's it.
They just collect it all.
If your computer ever breaks down - you can be anywhere in the world - get a new computer, set it up, plug in Carbonite and get all your data back.
It's so simple, anybody can use it.
And the reason I think this is important is because this is the first company to do it right.

And before this year is out, I predict that a major Internet company somewhere in America is either going to buy them or going to launch a similar service and this is going to become an industry standard that people are just going to take for granted worldwide.
Hiawatha Bray, good to talk to you.
Thanks so much.
Thank you.
That's Hiawatha Bray of the Boston Globe with some thoughts on what might be big on the Web in 2007.
For other ideas, we're joined now by Erin Ali.
She's an avid videogame player in Tempe, Arizona.
She wants to design games and is studying game development at the University of Advancing Technology.

To some extent, it's a healthy phenomenon because we were much the richest country in the world after World War II and the rest of the world, as it gradually catches up, its workers get paid more, it makes their things more expensive, and it makes their currencies worth more relative to the dollar.
So part of this is just normalization.
The part that's not fun, of course, is that it makes our economy smaller relative to others.
We're the world's policemen.
We pay for a lot of things.
It becomes more expensive to send troops abroad when the dollar doesn't go as far.
It becomes more expensive to be the world's policemen when you don't have as big a share of world income.
But that's a very gradual phenomenon, not something that's going to happen overnight.
But you look ahead 40 or 50 years and it's not so clear the dollar will be king any more.
Tell me about deficits and global debt.
To what extent does the accumulation of debt by our government, which has grown significantly over the last year, to what extent does that hurt the economy in the long run?
Well, it hurts the economy in the long run because eventually, you can't just keep running these deficits.
Eventually, you have to raise taxes or cut spending and that's no fun.
But we can trudge on like this for a while.

Eventually, however, we have to do something and the risk is that if we don't do it quickly enough, the market can boomerang on us rather suddenly and the way that would express itself is interest rates would rise quicker and more sharply than we expected.
Our interest payments would go up and our options would become more limited.
It would be better to get out ahead of it to set our budget trajectory on a better path a little sooner than later.
Not an easy situation after this financial crisis.
We hear about a V-shaped recovery where we're now at the bottom of the V and we'll go up pretty quickly.
We hear about a U-shaped recovery where that will happen more slowly, a double dip recession.
What letters are you looking at here?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I can barely spell my name.
I don't know.
The V-shape signifies this, you go down really fast and you go up really fast and that is the norm.
If you look at most postwar recessions in the United States, the deep recessions had big bouncing recoveries but this wasn't typical.
This was a banking panic, a financial crisis.
It's worse.
So I think, you know, more like a U - I guess some people refer to where you grow but not at this fierce rate that you're used to.
And I'm afraid that we may have slower growth for a long time, not just for a few years.
The U.S.
economy had growth before the crisis.
Some of it wasn't real.
Some of it we saw in housing, some of it in the financial sector and I think our expectations are going to have to adjust downwards a bit afterwards.
You know, it's not the end of world.
I mean, we'll be growing maybe better than we did in the '70s but not like we did in this boom period in the run up to the crisis.
Kenneth Rogoff is an economics professor at Harvard and the co-author of ""This Time Is Different: Eight Centuries of Financial Folly.
Ken Rogoff, thanks for being with us.
It's my pleasure.
At this hour, Senator Kennedy's body is being flown here to Washington, D.C.
for burial across the Potomac River near his brothers at Arlington National Cemetery.
NPR's Brian Naylor is at the cemetery.
Brian, Senator Kennedy's body hasn't yet arrived.
What are you seeing in Arlington now?
Guy, I'm overlooking the gravesite.
I can see the eternal flame that burns at President John F.
Kennedy's gravesite.
To his right is Robert F.
Kennedy's and Edward Kennedy will be buried next to Robert about a hundred feet from there.
It's a spectacular sight, Guy.
You can overlook all of Washington, the Washington Monument, the Capitol Building, and the Lincoln Memorial is on a direct access to the graves.
It's a beautiful view.
And right now, there are small groups of people that are lining.
I can see Memorial Bridge and the drive that leads into Arlington; there are small groups of people that are lining the way.
There are TV cameras positioned in satellite trucks and everybody is just kind of awaiting for the Hearse and the motorcade to arrive right now.
Brian, I know this is a closed ceremony.
Mm-hmm.
But can you give us an idea of what's being planned?
It's going to take about 20 minutes they're telling us.
It will be led by Cardinal Theodore McCarrick, who is the Archbishop Emeritus of Washington, someone who Senator Kennedy worked with on inner city Catholic schools and other social programs.
There will be a joint casket team comprised of the various branches of the military that will carry the Hearse to the gravesite.
There will be three volleys of military rifle team.
There will be Taps.
And we're also expecting to hear from two of Senator Kennedy's grandchildren as well as perhaps Vice President Biden, who's scheduled to be here.
That's NPR's Brian Naylor.
He's graveside at Arlington National Cemetery where Senator Kennedy will be laid to rest soon.
Brian, thanks so much.
Thank you, Guy.
(Soundbite of music)
New York state has been abuzz with speculation about just who might fill Hillary Clinton's vacant Senate seat.
Clinton was confirmed yesterday as secretary of state.
But David Paterson, the Democratic governor of New York, has yet to name a successor.
He's expected to do so very soon.
Caroline Kennedy was said to be a top contender, but word came last night that she was dropping out.
She cited personal reasons.
Shocking.

Yes, it's what's it sounds like - it keeps the sun off your can of brew.
